Award.AwardTitle: Building a Community to Pursue Quantitative Cell Biology

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
The cell is the basic building block of all life, and the development of methods to understand (and more important, predict) how cells "compute" decisions about their behavior would mark a major advance in our ability to understand, build and control living organisms. While most of the molecular components of the cell have been identified, the emergence of cell structure and behavior from molecular interactions remains a fundamentally mysterious process. Computer simulations, mathematical models, and quantitative measurement approaches inspired by physics are being brought to bear on the cell biological question of how cells are put together and function. But in contrast to many established fields within biology, such as biochemistry or genetics, quantitative cell biology as a field of its own is still relatively new and not strongly established. The goal of this project is to bring together disparate researchers working on quantitative approaches to the cell, to help them join into a community with its own identity and share the methods and ideas that individual researchers have developed in their own groups. This will be achieved through a variety of mechanisms that include the web-based community exchange of ideas and social coding to develop novel computational tools. Multiple focused workshops will be held as well as larger community meetings, and the support of undergraduate and graduate student interdisciplinary training will be supported through laboratory exchange visits and facilitation of their participation in workshops and conferences. The community will be inclusive of all researchers interested in furthering the goals of quantitative cell biology, and efforts will be directed towards reaching out to, inviting and supporting the participation of women and groups under-represented in the field. By bringing together researchers sharing a common interest in quantitative cell biology, using web-based activities, a series of focused workshops and laboratory exchange opportunities, this project will accelerate the pace at which this new field develops.

A fundamental unsolved problem in biology is to understand the cell as an emergent living structure resulting from thousands or millions of components working collectively; in order to achieve this, quantitative and computational approaches are required that do not currently exist. Only by re-thinking cell biology as a fully quantitative science on a par with condensed matter physics will it be possible to go beyond "one protein at a time" studies and understand how the cell as a whole is able to function. To advance this goal a series of highly interactive and focused workshops will be organized on topics that include the framework for standardization of data and algorithms for the analysis of microscope images; the challenge of scale in modeling cellular processes; the development of numerical methods and the application of information theory in cell biology; and the training of a new generation of quantitative cell biologists. Inter-disciplinary scientific laboratory exchange visits for undergraduate and graduate students will be supported, as well as the attendance of students (including especially women and groups under-represented in the field) at workshops and meetings in quantitative cell biology.

This award is supported jointly by the Cellular Dynamics and Function Cluster in the Division of Molecular and Cellular Biosciences and by the Program in Mathematical Biology in the Division of Mathematical Sciences.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The cell is the basic building block of all life, and in this sense understanding how life works depends on understanding how cells work.  Due to many advances in the fields of molecular biology and biochemistry, we have a thorough knowledge of the molecules that the cell is built from, but we still know far less about how the molecules work together to enable cells to grow, divide, and move.  To fill this gap in our knowledge, we need to apply methods from physics and computation, methods that have been developed in the “hard science” fields (physics, chemistry, etc.) to study and predict the behavior of complex systems.   Traditionally, cell biologists are not trained in these methods.  At the same time, mathematical and computational biologists have traditionally applied their concepts and tools to study biochemical reactions or population dynamics, but not to cell biology.   As a result, the people who are asking the questions about how cells work are often not equipped to answer those questions using quantitative techniques, while the people with the mathematical or computational skills that are needed in cell biology often are unaware of the interesting problems that arise when thinking about cells.

 

The goal of our program has been to promote quantitative cell biology as a field, by bringing people together with different training and expertise to think together about problems of mutual interest.  Our primary approach was to organize a series of small, highly interactive workshops, that brought together attendees from a range of different fields (traditional cell biology, biophysics, mathematical biology, mechanical engineering, computer science, condensed matter physics, bioinformatics, to name a few).  Initially, these workshops were designed to focus on specific topics such as visualization in cell biology, and were structured as a series of short talks, but with more time for free discussion than a typical scientific conference.  During the last few years of the program, we moved to a more interactive format, which we termed a “cell modeling hackathon” based on the hackathon concept that has become common in the technology industry.  In our hackathons, we brought together roughly equal numbers of attendees from cell biology and from computational/physical sciences, for a three day session in which attendees formed teams of 2-4 people who worked together to create new mathematical models for various aspects of cell biology.  Here, by model we mean either a set of equations that predicts how a cell behaviors (similar to the way equations are used to model the motion of planets in astronomy) or else computer simulations that represent how molecules interact in the cell (similar to the way video games represent the motion and interaction of characters in the game).  The main goal of these events was not so much creating the models, but to launch new collaborations between the participants.  A second goal was to provide traditional cell biologists more appreciation of computational methods and to provide computational scientists with appreciation of the open questions in cell biology.   In all, we organized 14 events through this program, bringing together hundreds of participants.  We have set up a social media group on LinkedIn to help former attendees keep in touch, and it currently has over 500 members. 

 

Probably the most important tangible outcome is that the workshop, and especially the hackathons, have directly launched new collaborations among scientists who had never met each other before.   Sixteen of these collaborations have been so active that they have produced scientific papers or research grant proposals.  Others have given joint talks at meetings, exchanged students between labs, and started working together in other ways.   This program has thus directly driven a new, interactive group of researchers working together to make cell biology more quantitative.

 

A broader impact outcome has been to promote training of students in quantitative cell biology.  The program supported the travel of undergraduate and graduate students to attend conferences that would enhance their training in quantitative cell biology (for example, funding travel of students from physics backgrounds to attend cell biology conferences, or cell biology students to attend physics meetings).   The program has also supported summer research experiences for biology students in which they have learned methods of quantitative biology.  Many students involved in these elements of the program also participated in the workshops or hackathons.

 

Finally, the program has resulted in increased awareness among cell biologists of the growing field of quantitative cell biology.  Our social media presence has been steadily gaining visibility.   When we first started our workshop series, we were easily able to accommodate everyone who wanted to attend, but by the end of the program, the number of applications greatly exceeded the capacity of the meetings and we had to turn many people away.  We view this increased awareness of the field as an important outcome of the work.
